section.name: Getting Involved with Apache Tuscany
section.p:
You can get involved in Apache Tuscany in many different ways. The following are a few suggestions:
Contribute new ideas/requirements that are based on real business experiences to the mailing list to improve Tuscany as a solution for SOA.
Answer questions posted to the mailing lists.
Contribute to the FAQ or to linkNewWindow('http://wiki.apache.org/ws/Tuscany','Wiki');
Contribute to user or developer Documentations.
Investigate linkNewWindow('http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/BrowseProject.jspa?id=12310210','issues'); that have been reported and provide patches.
Help with development. Check for roadmap on the Wiki.
Help with linkNewWindow('samples/java/readme.htm','Tuscany Samples'); to demonstrate Tuscany's value and help new users understand Tuscany

Before you start, join Tuscany mailing list. At the moment we only have one mailing list that handles both developer and user questions.
Subscription: Send a blank email to tuscany-dev-subscribe@ws.apache.org
Posting questions to the list: Send your question to tuscany-dev@ws.apache.org
You should also review linkNewWindow('http://www.apache.org/foundation/how-it-works.html','How Apache works');.

section.name: How to get involved
section.p:
Apache Tuscany source code, documentation and web site are managed under version control using Subversion in linkNewWindow('https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/tuscany','Tuscany Subversion Repository');. In this repository structure you will find two main directories
1) CPP directory holds SCA and SDO C++ source code
2) Java directory holds SCA, SDO and DAS source code.

section.name: Get Started On Tuscany Using Java

span.span: The Tuscany Java projects depend on J2SE version 5.x which can be downloaded here:

ul.li: The Java project is built using linkNewWindow('http://maven.apache.org/','Apache Maven 2');

The Tuscany runtime can be used as a server in conjunction with Tomcat, which you can find here: linkNewWindow('http://tomcat.apache.org/','http:/tomcat.apache.org');
Download "The Core" Tomcat 5.5.xx from:
http://tomcat.apache.org/download-55.cgi
For setting up Tomcat to run Tuscany see the sample's readme linkNewWindow('samples/java/readme.htm#Tomcat_Setup','Tomcat Setup'); in the sample's readme.

section.p: You can use any IDE. Tuscany has a preferred way of running from within Eclipse and IDEA. This is documented below. You will also find high level introduction for maven 2.0 as well as subversion in the text below.

section.name: Using Subversion (Command Line)
section.p: You can download Subversion from linkNewWindow('http://subversion.tigris.org/','http://subversion.tigris.org/');.
Subversion Reference manual ("the book") is located at linkNewWindow('http://svnbook.red-bean.com/','http://svnbook.red-bean.com/');.

p.span: If you use Eclipse as your development environment, there is a plugin available which enables you to use Subversion from within Eclipse (ie it is a Subversion client for Eclipse). This plugin is called Subclipse and it is located at: linkNewWindow('http://subclipse.tigris.org/','http://subclipse.tigris.org/');

If you use Windows on your systems, there is also a graphical client implemented as an extension to the Windows shell, called TortoiseSVN:
http://tortoisesvn.tigris.org/

section.p:
Create a directory called tuscany and check out the project.
To check out the Java project:
section.pre: Committers: svn co https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/tuscany/java Non-Commiters: svn co http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/tuscany/java

b.i: To check out the C++ project:

section.pre: Committers: svn co https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/tuscany/cpp Non-Commiters: svn co http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/tuscany/cpp
section.p: If it worked, you will see all the files as they checkout followed by a revision number - this is the version of the tree that you have (useful for comparing notes)

b.i: To update your copy with other's people's committed changes:
To manipulate files in various ways:

section.pre:
svn add
svn move
svn remove
svn diff

b.i: To commit changes go to the root and:

section.p: This will commit the entire tree and display the new revision number. You can also commit sub-trees and individual files but this is not normal.

b.i: To see what has changed locally:

section.p: A means a file has been added locally
D means a file has been deleted locally
M means a file has been modified locally

? means a file exists locally that is not being managed by svn.
Typically this means you forgot to add it with svn add .

! means a file that was being managed by svn no longer exists locally.
Typically this means you didn't delete it using svn remove.

section.name: Using Eclipse (optional)
section.p:
Getting Started documentation:
http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/index.php
To create the eclipse projects to use for SCA development:

1) When checking code out from subversion, checkout the subversion trunk to a location outside your eclipse workspace (it has to be outside because Eclipse will not allow you to import projects from a location overlapping with your workspace)

2) Go to Import / Existing projects into workspace.
Select either the runtime, spec, tools or samples directory.
The wizard proposes the list of Eclipse projects under that directory. Importing the projects does not copy the files; it just makes the files at that location visible under an Eclipse project.

3) If you need to use Eclipse to edit files outside of these projects (for example the etc directory, or the maven files at the root of the trunk), then delete the Eclipse projects, with the option to not delete the files, and import the whole trunk as a project.

If you are using Eclpse, Tuscany has a preferred Java coding style. Please use the tuscany-eclipse-codestyle.xml in Eclipse.
Download this file. You may need to right click and save. Then in Eclipse:
Window->Preferences->Java->Code-Style->Formatter->Import... (Specify path and file to the tuscany-eclipse-codestyle.xml just downloaded.

section.name: Using Subclipse (optional)
section.p: Install the Subversion Eclipse Plugin as described here: http://subclipse.tigris.org/

ol.li: Open the SVN Repository Exploring perspective
Right click in the SVN Repository view.

Url:
http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/tuscany
Use URL https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/tuscany if you have committer rights and need to commit changes back to the repository.

Select the "Finish" button and allow Subclipse time to access the repository and display its contents in the SVN Repository explorer. Once the repository is displayed in the explorer, you will see a number of subfolders displayed. The ones that are relevant are "java", "cpp" and "site" - which contain the Tuscany Java runtime, the Tuscany C++ runtime and the Tuscany website material respectively.

Select the folder you want to check out as a project - one of java, cpp or site for example Right click, select "Checkout" and "Checkout using new project wizard" - select the appropriate options for your needs and then click "Finish"

section.p: You can check in changes using the "Commit" item in the team submenu of the Java perspective.

section.name: Using Maven
section.p: Tuscany uses Maven 2.x. Maven can be found here: linkNewWindow('http://maven.apache.org/','http://maven.apache.org/');
For some help getting started with Maven, look at: linkNewWindow('http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html','http://maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html');

With Maven, there is no build "script" like the ant build.xml file. Instead you provide Maven with a description of your project and it uses that information to determine how to achieve your build goal. The description is held in a pom.xml file. There is a pom.xml file at the top level of your project and there are subsidiary pom.xml files for modules within your project which are referenced from the top level pom file. The Maven project has also established a set of best practices for structuring builds and if you follow those you can get away with very little description; the Tuscany builds are set up that way.

The general rule for maven is that each (sub)project produces one build artifact (typically a jar file). You can see this in the java project directory where there are separate projects for sca, sdo, das (etc) and within these, separate folders and pom files for major components such as container.java.

The main Maven 2.x command is "mvn" and the default goal is "install" which will compile, unit test and package each project. This will typically output a jar file that is installed locally so that other projects can depend on it.

To build the Java project once you have Maven and Java SDK set up in your path, in the SVN checked out java directory:
mvn
